title: 114_s1989
content: The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" allows for direct primary care service arrangements where individuals pay a fixed fee for ongoing primary care services, not billed to third parties. This arrangement is not considered a health plan or insurance. The amendment applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include periodic provider fees as medical care. This applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 establishes the Medicare Primary Care Medical Home Demonstration Program. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a Primary Care Medical Home Model where qualified practices are reimbursed for services provided to individuals enrolled under part B of title XVIII. The Primary Care Medical Home Model reimburses qualified practices for services provided to individuals enrolled under part B of title XVIII. The Secretary establishes a periodic fee for each individual enrolled in the practice. The Primary Care Medical Home Model sets a monthly fee for individuals enrolled in the practice, capped at twenty percent of estimated per capita monthly costs from Federal Trust Funds. The Secretary also establishes performance benchmarks using ACO quality measures. The Primary Care Medical Home Model establishes performance benchmarks using ACO quality measures for participating practices. If a qualified practice meets or exceeds the benchmark, they will receive a periodic fee for each enrolled individual. The Primary Care Medical Home Model sets performance benchmarks for participating practices. If a practice fails to meet the benchmark for two consecutive years, their participation in the model will be terminated. Fees for enrolled individuals will be adjusted based on performance. The qualified direct primary care medical home practice must provide preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, coordination with specialty and hospital care, availability of appointments 7 days a week, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and 24/7 telephone access for ongoing care consultation. The qualified direct primary care medical home practice must offer 24/7 telephone access for ongoing care consultation and prioritize enrolling dual eligible individuals. The term 'dual eligible individual' refers to someone enrolled in part B of title XVIII and meets specific criteria under the Social Security Act. Care provided in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under this model is not considered insurance and is not regulated as such by State insurance commissioners. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice participating in the model under this subsection must report annually to the Secretary on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions, including emergency room visits, hospitalizations, surgeries, specialist visits, and use of advanced radiology. The Secretary will provide qualified direct primary care medical home practices with necessary patient data for clinical purposes and evaluation of the model. Physicians who have opted out of Medicare may still participate in the program. Physicians who have opted out of Medicare can participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under the model, but those excluded from federal health care programs cannot. The Secretary will oversee the model's duration. The Secretary will conduct the model for at least 3 years. After the third year, qualified direct primary care practices meeting requirements can continue permanently. After 3 years, if a majority of qualified direct primary care practices meet the requirements, the Secretary will expand the model nationwide. The text chunk discusses the use of direct primary care medical homes under the Medicare Advantage program. The text chunk allows Medicare Advantage organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices to offer primary care services and share savings. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice is defined as described in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
